title: Cities of Refuge
shortSummary: Numbers 35 details God's instructions to Moses regarding the allocation of cities for the Levites and the establishment of six cities of refuge. These cities provide sanctuary for those who commit manslaughter unintentionally, ensuring justice and mercy within Israel’s legal system. The chapter emphasizes the holiness of the land and the importance of preserving life and justice under God’s law.
timeline: c. 1445 BC - Wilderness Wanderings, just before entering the Promised Land

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who receives God's commands regarding the cities for the Levites and the cities of refuge.

keyCharacters.name: Levites
keyCharacters.description: The tribe set apart for priestly duties, who are given cities to dwell in rather than a territorial inheritance.

keyCharacters.name: The Manslayer
keyCharacters.description: A person who kills another unintentionally and is protected by fleeing to a city of refuge.

keyCharacters.name: The Revenger of Blood
keyCharacters.description: A family member who has the right to pursue a murderer or manslayer, enforcing justice according to the law.

definitions.definition: An ancient measurement of length based on the distance from the elbow to the tip of the middle finger, approximately 18 inches.
Special cities designated to protect those who commit accidental manslaughter from revenge until a fair trial.
One who kills another person unintentionally or without premeditation.
A relative who seeks to avenge the death of a family member, especially in cases of murder.
The land surrounding the cities given to the Levites, used for their livestock and goods.

outline.heading: Instructions for Levite Cities and Their Suburbs
outline.description: God commands Moses to instruct Israel to allocate cities and surrounding lands to the Levites, who receive no tribal inheritance. These cities include six designated as cities of refuge.

outline.heading: Establishment and Purpose of Cities of Refuge
outline.description: God instructs the appointment of six cities of refuge, three on each side of the Jordan, to provide sanctuary for those who kill unintentionally, protecting them from the avenger of blood.

outline.heading: Distinction Between Murder and Manslaughter
outline.description: The chapter defines murder as intentional killing and mandates the death penalty, while distinguishing it from accidental killing, which allows for refuge.

outline.heading: Legal Procedures for Manslayers and the Role of the Congregation
outline.description: The congregation judges cases between manslayers and avengers, ensuring the manslayer remains in refuge until the high priest’s death, after which they may return home safely.

outline.heading: Statutes on Murder and Sanctity of the Land
outline.description: The chapter concludes with laws requiring multiple witnesses for capital cases, forbidding ransom for murderers, and emphasizing that bloodshed defiles the land, which can only be cleansed by justice.

application: Trust in God's provision of justice and mercy by respecting His laws and seeking refuge in Him during times of guilt and fear.
Practice forgiveness and patience, recognizing the difference between intentional harm and accidental mistakes in relationships and community life.
Commit to living holy lives that honor God’s presence in the land, avoiding actions that defile or bring harm to others.
Support and uphold biblical justice in the church and society, ensuring fairness and protection for the innocent.

keyVerses.text: Then ye shall appoint you cities to be cities of refuge for you; that the slayer may flee thither, which killeth any person at unawares.
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes the cities of refuge as God’s provision for mercy and protection for those who sin unintentionally.

keyVerses.text: Whoso killeth any person, the murderer shall be put to death by the mouth of witnesses: but one witness shall not testify against any person to cause him to die.
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the importance of due process and multiple witnesses in capital cases, safeguarding justice.

keyVerses.text: So ye shall not pollute the land wherein ye are: for blood it defileth the land: and the land cannot be cleansed of the blood that is shed therein, but by the blood of him that shed it.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the holiness of the land and the necessity of justice to maintain its sanctity.
